text:
I suspect that is meant to be tongue-in-cheek, but FWIW, because they’re so fast to train, we actually use them in situations where there’s streaming data coming in real-time, to train on-line(-ish) models (which we use along side gradient algorithms that were trained using 100's of hours of GPUs).

There may be better methods available, but what we have works pretty well!

(That said, I generally agree with the points made about gradient algorithms.)
